I don't often write reviews to films that I watch off unless they are something special. Wolf Children is just that. I'm not going to include any spoilers in here, or go into analysis of the plot. However, let me tell you that this film will move you. Numerous times during my viewing I was taken aback at how emotionally powerful this film was. Countless times throughout I was astounded at the summation of the film's parts. Soundtrack, plot, animation, all of these working in perfect tangent to create something utterly spectacular. Watch this film .

A simultaneously neo-Gothic and slice-of-life fairy tale about a single mother struggling to raise her two lycanthropic kids, Wolf Children is, in no unclear way, an unapologetically sentimental and heedlessly optimistic film. These sorts of affairs rarely go well. As serious movie watchers, we're tuned to appreciate explorations of misery and darkness - there's drama to be mined there, and psychological depths to be explored. Plus, bad things just seem more real. Usually when a film wears its smiling heart on its sleeve, its easily dismissed as too cute, too sappy, too naive. And oftentimes they are, - look no further than my About Time review - and deserve to be banished to the one-dimensional phantom zone of, oh I dunno, let's say the Hallmark Channel and movies that come out in February.That's why I so admire when fiction can be hopeful and escape the trappings of simplicity or silliness. The Friday Night Lights TV series is perhaps the pinnacle of this sort of storytelling, and it demonstrates that, in addition to many other things, naturalism and a generous heaping of hardship and tragedy are necessary to tell a believable, quality tale about good people triumphing through hard times. Wolf Children adheres to this sort of approach, serving up a strong backbone forged in pain and cruelty to temper the bright-eyed sweetness of mother Hana, keeping her buoyancy from turning the film into a mushy sack of pap. This results in each moment of unleashed glee, each bit of warmth, every small victory all feeling earned. Well, almost all. The film toes its line finely, and perhaps I was willing to overlook a few instances where it veered into mawkish territory simply because I was enjoying myself so much. Mileage will vary.The film itself is lushly animated, evoking Studio Ghibli's (most specifically My Neighbor Totoro) love of nature and aplomb at fading detail in and out of characters and scenes to great effect. I watched the film dubbed, as I usually don't have a problem doing so with anime films, and found the experience preferable to watching a few minutes with subtitles. Not only did the English voice-over seem more affecting, it has the most obvious benefit of allowing the viewer to focus on the rich and vibrant visuals without having to track words on the screen.Though Wolf Children could possibly be billed as a children's film, it's plenty mature, not only for the aforementioned darker moments, but also because so much of it feels like a novelistic exploration of growing up, of making a new home, of isolation and loneliness. It takes an impressively multi-faceted track to what could have been a fairly gimmicky concept - werewolves among us - and delivers a very organic, deeply human story. There are moments of melodrama, where the film takes advantage of certain leniencies afforded by its cartoon format to exaggerate emotions or compact moments that would otherwise need to breathe. It isn't, by far, a perfect film. It wears at the edges and can sometimes be too nice for its own good, and because it places such an emphasis on being able to tug at the viewer's heartstrings, each personal experience may be wildly different. But I found this one hitting in all the right places, and while a more professional reviewer might stick with a lower rating, I get to throw a little half star on top for my personal bias. It really is a lovely film.85/100

reviews.review_title: The world's a better place when we embrace individuality with acceptance and understanding.
reviews.content: We love our families. We cannot imagine our lives without our families. Parents make incredible sacrifices to ensure that their children are blessed with the best lives possible - that they enjoy their lives and don't feel left out while growing up. Parents face various hardships and challenges to take care of their offsprings. They go moon and back to ensure the safety and well-being of their children.Wolf Children, I feel, is a film about family, love, acceptance, understanding, unity & how to embrace being different. It teaches me what it means to be different, what it means to accept each other's uniqueness and flaws, how to accept everyone for who and what they are, how to carve your own niche while navigating through that uniqueness and, I dare say, how to use the uniqueness to your advantage in the world. The plot of the movie juggles atleast 5 genres simultaneously with spotless precision and quality: romance, drama, inspiration, feel-good and coming-of-age. I've never seen a movie quite like Wolf Children. That's why, it's one of the best and one of the most complete movies I've ever seen.After losing her husband and the father of her children, the way in which Hana gives her children the freedom to choose their own lives was very motivational. It must have been so difficult for her to deal with his death, then worry about the lives of her children and then make sensible decisions to make sure that her life and that of her kids was not in jeopardy. Moving from a city to go live in the countryside, to completely alter your lifestyle, might have been such a nerve-wracking experience. But the way in which she handled the situation & the transition was so beautiful to see. She started a new life, grew her own veggies to cut cost, worked hard tirelessly to make ends meet, again doing everything not for herself but for her children. She did have help along the way but by and large, she was successful in doing all of this alone.The film also tells me a lot about what it means to be a mother and, considering the bigger picture, what it means being a single parent raising kids. Being a mother is a thankless job and is sometimes taken for granted by some. I'm extremely thankful to our mothers for everything that they've done for our families. They're really the foundations upon which the structure of our lives rests.Throughout the movie, I always wondered how different their lives could've been if their father was still alive. The movie is a real tearjerker. The film has various moments that are so pure & emotional that they were difficult to watch. Having empathy for the characters as a viewer is tough sometimes.The end of the movie is pretty hard to watch. When the son chooses his own path to live as wolf in the mountains was the moment I felt that she did an excellent job raising her kids. She was a great mother who never imposed her decisions upon her kids. Her daughter wanted to live as a human and her son wanted to live as a wolf. She was an intelligent and inspirational mother. Her spirit was indomitable. Although it was hard at the beginning, she made peace with their choices eventually. She let them express their individuality without prejudice. Her objective was completed. Another scene at the end where the daughter reveals to her friend that she is a wolf felt like the circle of life was completed. Her own father revealed being a wolf to her mother and then she revealed being a wolf to her friend at school. But he knew, didn't he? He was always ready to accept her for who she was. That was very mature of him. That's why, I believe that the coming-of-age aspect of the movie is outstanding and one of the best things about it. They've shown and explained every perspective very nicely.Wolf Children taught me about acceptance, understanding & embracing the flaws & your own individuality. We are all different & we come from different places. The world can be a difficult place to coexist but with the help of our families, friends and most importantly, with our self-belief and faith, it is, by no means, an insurmountable challenge.

reviews.review_title: This review will not be long. Watch this film!
reviews.content: This review will not be long. I will simply say, because I must say this right now. reviews.review_title: Not as good as Summer Wars, but decent
reviews.content: Summer Wars was one of my favorite anime's ever so after getting to see a trailer for Wolf Children, I was pumped. I finally got the blu-ray and watched it. The good: - The art, design, and vision is fantasticThe emotional aspect is there, I felt tied to the mom and eventually the wolf-children (though the sister more than the brother by the end)Good pace. It's on the slower-side, but I think it shows the country life vs the city life (which had a faster pace at the beginning) by doing so.The so-so: - A few characters are introduced about 1/3 or 1/2 way through the movie that you think are going to develop into part of the main picture (grandpa farmer, the boy who gets attacked by Yuki, the fox elder), but are little-to-nothing in the scheme of the movie... which was disappointing to me cause some of them were very memorable.The idea of wolf people was kind of glossed over. I didn't necessarily mind not getting a scientific breakdown but when the rest of the world is normal yet we have a few wolf people, it draws me out of the movie more. The bad: - I think they started great with the stories of the family and how they grew together, and the class-room evolution/growth scene was fantastic. After that scene, though, when the siblings are more independent, I felt drawn away from both and felt like the attention wasn't distributed right. I think had they focused on the sister more and left the brother more a mystery, it would've worked better.The ending was pretty weak IMO. The reason being that, as mentioned before, they spent time developing minor characters with the expectation (for me at least) that it would impact the characters or you'd see why the movie showed them so often. For me, the ending kind of threw all of that out and said "oh well here's what happened after the kids were done w/ elementary school.... see ya". I didn't like it and it felt rushed / unfulfilled which for me dropped the movie from what would be an 8.5 or 9 out of 10 given the other points... to a 7/10.

reviews.review_title: An emotional story that will leave you filled with tears of happiness.
reviews.content: Wolf Children is a touching story about Hana, a single mother, raising two young children, Yuki and Ame. The story starts by showing Hana at Tokyo National University, where she meets the love of her life, which has a secret. He is a wolf-man. The last one to have both wolf and man in his blood, and is able to change between man and wolf at will. They have two children together, Yuki and Ame, and they live together in their apartment in Tokyo for a couple years, until the father unfortunately dies. Due to increasing pressure from her landlord, and Child Protective Services, Hana decides to move to the country, where she lets her children decide their own path. To grow up as normal human children, or to answer the call of the wild.I personally found this a fantastically well-told story with amazing animation. Wolf Children, I was entrapped at the first second, and the story left me hanging on until the credits were rolling. The characters are well developed, and the animation is really well drawn. I would rate this movie 8/10, and would recommend anyone who enjoys anime movies to watch this.

Together with my 14-year old son I went to see an exhibition on the world of Manga in the ethnographic museum in Rotterdam (Wereldmuseum). An entire room was dedicated to the artwork of the internationally acclaimed anime Wolf Children Ame and Yuki from director Mamoru Hosoda. The beautiful original watercolours we saw there used as backgrounds inspired us to go see the movie. What an experience it was: the main character a student who is so open-minded that she marries a 'wolfman', the last surviving in Japan. Of course very interesting to see what happens when they get babies -half wolf half child- and how to raise them. The movie is at times sad and heart-breaking and at times very funny. But all the time very calm and zen and beautiful. Seldom I saw an animated movie with so much emotion in the movements of the characters. A beautiful fairy-tale!
